image.altText: Lara Alexander wears a black coat and blue and pink scarf and stands on a suburban Launceston street

items.synopsis: Newly-independent MP Lara Alexander says a "huge weight" has been lifted from her shoulders, while the Tasmanian Greens' push to axe Hobart's new stadium look set for failure without Labor's support.

title.children: 'A huge weight lifted': MP relieved after becoming an independent, but headaches ahead for now-minority government

image.altText: A composite of images of a young and old Mick Doleman and a shipwreck under the ocean.

items.synopsis: The wreck of the Blythe Star is located almost 50 years after it sank off the Tasmanian coast, its crew believed dead — until, astonishingly, they appeared out of the bush far from where the ship sank.

title.children: It was the largest maritime search Australia had ever held. 50 years later, it's over

image.altText: Jasmina, woman in pink sihrt smiling, holding a baby wearing a blue shirt.

items.synopsis: Michelle and Jono Harley always dreamed of having a family — their devastating fertility journey took a twist when relatives stepped in with an extraordinary back-up plan.

title.children: 'They need an oven and I have to cook it': Why Jasmina, 52, gave birth to her grandson

image.altText: An older white man in heavily armoured combat gear and a helmet stands on a rooftop, with a soldier looking out behind him.

items.synopsis: Today, as Russia's President Vladimir Putin flails around dispatching one failed military chief after another, Yevgeny Prigozhin – for the moment at least – is probably the safest Russian in the world, writes John Lyons in Kyiv.

title.children: Is this the safest Russian in the world? Perhaps, as long as he keeps Putin happy

image.altText: Composite image of a Korean man smiling and an Australian woman smiling.

items.synopsis: As South Korea edges closer to being solely powered by renewables come 2050, the manufacturing industries of Australia's third-largest trading partner believe hydrogen gas is the answer to help reach its target.

title.children: South Korea will be powered solely by renewables by 2050 — and it's relying on Australian hydrogen to make it happen

image.altText: Three mugshots of three separate men. The first has tattoos on his face. The second has a beard. The third has darker skin.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Manhunt for three escaped prisoners, and an NBA star suspended over a new gun video. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A manhunt is underway after three men escaped from a Queensland prison on Sunday. The men escaped from Palen Creek Correctional Centre, which is about 100 kilometres southwest of Brisbane. Authorities are now on the hunt for Daniel Ian Badcock, 32; Osiah Pilton, 20; and Antonio David Mene, 28. Badcock was serving a one year sentence for possession and weapons charges. He is described as having a medium build, with a diamond tattoo on the left side of his face and the word 'Opmerta' tattooed over his right eye. He has other tattoos including the word 'Outlaw' on his left shin and knuckle dusters tattooed onto his right hand Pilton, who was serving one year and nine months for a break and enter offence, is described as having black hair and eyes with the word 'Mum' tattooed on his left arm above the wrist, and a diamond tattoo on his left leg Mene who was serving three years for vehicular offences, is described by police as being Torres Strait Islander, about 170 cm tall with the outline of his last name tattooed on the inside of his right arm Police have urged anyone who has seen the men not to approach them but to call triple zero.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Manhunt underway after three men escape a Queensland prison

props.alt: Three mug shots of men, one with a beard and one with tattoos on his face

children.content: (AAP: Queensland Police)
A manhunt is underway after three men escaped from a Queensland prison on Sunday.
The men escaped from Palen Creek Correctional Centre, which is about 100 kilometres southwest of Brisbane.
Authorities are now on the hunt for
Daniel Ian Badcock, 32; Osiah Pilton, 20; and Antonio David Mene, 28

Badcock was serving a one year sentence for possession and weapons charges. He is described as having a medium build, with a diamond tattoo on the left side of his face and the word 'Opmerta' tattooed over his right eye. He has other tattoos including the word 'Outlaw' on his left shin and knuckle dusters tattooed onto his right hand

Pilton, who was serving one year and nine months for a break and enter offence, is described as having black hair and eyes with the word 'Mum' tattooed on his left arm above the wrist, and a diamond tattoo on his left leg

Mene who was serving three years for vehicular offences, is described by police as being Torres Strait Islander, about 170 cm tall with the outline of his last name tattooed on the inside of his right arm
Police have urged anyone who has seen the men not to approach them but to call triple zero.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After passing over Bangladesh's Saint Martin's Island, Cyclone Mocha has hit Myanmar, tearing roofs off buildings and killing at least three people. The cyclone made landfall on Sunday afternoon in Myanmar's Rakhine state near Sittwe township, with winds of up to 209 kilometers per hour, Myanmar's Meteorological Department says —making the storm a dangerous category five cyclone. The extent of the damage in Sittwe isn't clear just yet. Earlier yesterday, high winds crumpled mobile phone towers, cutting off communications in much of the area. In videos collected by local media before communications were cut off, deep water races through streets while wind lashes trees and pulls boards off roofs. Myanmar's military information office says the storm damaged houses, electrical transformers, phone towers, boats and lampposts in Sittwe, Kyaukpyu, and Gwa townships. It says the storm also tore roofs off of sport buildings on the Coco Islands.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Cyclone Mocha has killed at least three people

props.alt: People walk through a flooded street in Myanmar

children.content: (AP)
After passing over Bangladesh's Saint Martin's Island, Cyclone Mocha has hit Myanmar, tearing roofs off buildings and
killing at least three people
The cyclone made landfall on Sunday afternoon in Myanmar's Rakhine state near Sittwe township, with
winds of up to 209 kilometers per hour
, Myanmar's Meteorological Department says —making the storm a dangerous category five cyclone.
The extent of the damage in Sittwe isn't clear just yet.
Earlier yesterday,
high winds crumpled mobile phone towers
, cutting off communications in much of the area.

props.alt: A map showing a cyclone over parts of India and Myanmar

children.content: (India Meteorological Department via AP)
In videos collected by local media before communications were cut off, deep water races through streets while wind lashes trees and pulls boards off roofs.

Myanmar's military information office says the storm damaged houses, electrical transformers, phone towers, boats and lampposts in Sittwe, Kyaukpyu, and Gwa townships. It says the storm also tore roofs off of sport buildings on the Coco Islands.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In basketball, NBA star Ja Morant has been suspended by the Memphis Grizzlies after he appeared to be holding a gun in another social media video that was streamed live on Instagram. It's the second time in less than three months that Morant has been seen on social media holding what appeared to be a weapon. The first led to an eight-game suspension which cost Morant about $US669,000 ($1 million) in salary. It's unclear what sanctions he might face for the second video. The Grizzlies, who are now out of the NBA playoffs, say Morant is suspended from all team activities "pending league review". The NBA says it is aware of the new video and is "gathering more information".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NBA star Ja Morant suspended over new gun video

props.alt: A black man playing basketball for Memphis approach the ring while holding the ball. A defender and opponents in the background

children.content: (AP: Jae C. Hong)
In basketball, NBA star Ja Morant has been suspended by the Memphis Grizzlies after he appeared to be holding a gun in another social media video that was streamed live on Instagram.
It's the second time in less than three months
that Morant has been seen on social media holding what appeared to be a weapon. The first led to an eight-game suspension which cost Morant about $US669,000 ($1 million) in salary.
It's unclear what sanctions he might face for the second video.
The Grizzlies, who are now out of the NBA playoffs, say Morant is
suspended from all team activities "pending league review"
The NBA says it is aware of the new video and is "gathering more information".

image.altText: A rescue boat in the water with at least four people on board.

image.altText: A line stretches back as far as the eye can see outside Centrelink.

image.altText: Person leaning over a table wearing a hooded gown, with a box of tissues and a mug on the table.

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a light blue shirt with his arms down and hands together

image.altText: A composite of Tasmanian MPs Lara Alexander and John Tucker in parliament.

items.synopsis: Tasmanian MPs Lara Alexander and John Tucker are moving to the crossbenches after quitting the Liberals, saying the government lacks transparency over deals like the AFL stadium. So who are they and how will they vote?

image.altText: Jim gestures as he speaks at a podium.

image.altText: Bernard Arnault stands between his two oldest children

image.altText: Ron DeSantis greets audience members during a fundraising picnic for U.S. Rep. Randy Feenstra

image.altText: Loreen performing on stage with hands out and a camera in front of her.

image.altText: a platypus is released into the waters of a national park

image.altText: sepia toned photograph of a young gary tonkin holding up the four-metre whale jaw on a wooden jetty.

items.synopsis: For 30 years, scrimshander Gary Tonkin, 74, scratched away on the jaw bone and teeth of a sperm whale, creating intricate engravings telling the story of an American whaling ship, The Kathleen, that went from hunter to hunted.

title.children: Delicate carvings on a giant whale jawbone tell a grim seafaring tale in this disappearing art form

image.altText: A woman and a man near Ayers Rock in Northern territory.

items.synopsis: A Queensland woman last seen on South Australia's western Eyre Peninsula a week ago is found by a member of the public who saw her "wandering out of the scrub". Her family say she's now recovering in hospital.

title.children: 'I just broke down': Family's relief as Queensland woman found a week after going missing in SA town

items.synopsis: A deep divide has arisen over the High Court and role it could play over a Voice to Parliament. For some, it's raising echoes of past Indigenous rights battles, writes Elizabeth Byrne.

image.altText: Unidentified Queensland Police Service officer

image.altText: A mother and daughter sitting in a chair, Kununurra 2023.

image.altText: A collage of three photos of people with their faces scratched out.

image.altText: Woman with hat standing in her crop in the bright warm morning sun
